attributes.comment:
I support this move.

Let me describe why.

I've been living in USA since 1999 as a full-time employee getting above market
wages and dutifully paying taxes. Recently, I became a home owner on a personal
level and a manager - managing people - in professional level. Still - after
making contributions to US economy - I feel , on a personal level, I am not
getting what I deserve.

For example, my wife just cannot work because I am waiting for my "Green Card"
retrogression to end for past several years. She's a driven individual and I
believe would make an excellent elementary teacher, a position she's passionate
about -- but she just cannot work! This is frustrating for both her and myself.

For example, when I went to shop for my mortgage, my non-permanent resident
status became a roadblock and eventually my interest rate, despite my 800+
credit score, was much higher than a 'resident' guy in a similar position. Yes,
I believe this is discriminatory.

For example, I work for a Fortune 10 company and am in a position where I feel
my earnings should rather be private since I too manage employees. But every
time my H1-B goes up for renewal, the salary just needs to be put up to the
board in front of the cafeteria exposing something very private to the rest of
the 150,000 employee company!

In a nutshell, I have and advanced engineering degree from one of the most
reputed institutes, 10 years of strong experience in my field, am paid very
well, have been contributing to American Economy for past 9 years -- and still
-- am lagging a person of similar stature -- but with residency or citizenship
-- in a lot of personal and financial things!

I can pay for the process to be more efficient, expedient and selecting the
'right' people by doing correct background checks. I can also understand the
premium one needs to pay for 'preferred' processing (like, the PERM processing
of Labor or I-140 application) -- and am more than willing to pay!

At the proposed increased fee levels, I believe the process would be more
efficient and expedited and people like me would benefit from it. At the same
time, I would urge to consider starting a "premium processing" for I-485
application too. This way both the BCIS and people like us benefit, and people
who cannot afford to pay don't lose out on anything (they're still on the queue!).
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Nilendu Misra, Hewlett-Packard Company
